name: This flow Runs on IoT Sandbox, with ParetoAnywhere Installed
info: This machine needs to have ParetoAnywhere installed.

name: When creating new BLE messages, use dynamb property names from here: https://reelyactive.github.io/diy/cheatsheet/#dynamb
This flow uses the ParetoAnywhere software to access Bluetooth Low-energy device information
You can access the Pareto Anywhere Apps here to see more device information: http://[THIS_MACHINE_IP]:3001/
Capturing all devices and saving their info, for the dashboard
save to allBLE
You can also use the "BLE Devices" page in the Node-red Dashboard to see what BLE devices ParetoAnywhere sees
CreateHTMLTableFromJSON
Untracked BLE Devices
getUNCapturedBLE
This creates a tab of all UNTRACKED BLE devices
Tracked BLE Devices
CreateHTMLTableFromJSON
getCapturedBLE
This creates a tab of all UNTRACKED BLE devices
the "BLE Devices" tab in the dashboard shows you which devices you're tracking, and which ones Pareto sees but you haven't tracked yet
This little bit is useful for debugging, for seeing all the data that pareto is getting, even if it's not decoded yet.
Connect Pareto top output to Split to get it going....
Looking for a particular device ID
Each tab to the right is a sample for access data from a different paret-compatible device. Take a look!
This part below helps us buld out the UI of known and unknown devices
/motionE8DA/isMotionDetected
Open the ParetoAnywhere Object to set a Device URI
create a friendly topic name, and assign the payload here
send via named LinkOut to the Message Switchboard running in another flow on this computer
Confirm the property of the right name exists...
Even if we trust the device....

true->1, false->0
split into 3
open the UI and look under "BLE Devices" to see devices, their deviceId, and deviceIdType values

send via named LinkOut to the Message Switchboard running in another flow on this computer
